posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Problem: When sending links from some websites and applications through Signal, the links can be ridiculously long (thanks to trackers) and they take up a lot of space in the conversation.
Example:

Screenshot_20200826-1950171440×2982 762 KB

This is only one link

Solution: Implement a link “cleaner” that automatically “cleans” the link, removes trackers and unnecessary parts, and makes the links much shorter.
Using a website like urlclean.com, I can show you what this would look like

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

While that could be nice, it would have to be very careful to avoid incorrectly “cleaning” a link.

Of course. I think what other services do is basically load the link, and then replace the sent link with the final URL of the page once it loads. (I don’t know anything about how this works, so that’s just a guess). This way, the link always takes you where you want to go.

Oh god, I subscribe to this. Literally yesterday I wanted to create the same feature request, but haven’t got the time.

Regarding @Herohtar concern about cleaning the URL correctly, I can say we (not me, but the devs I work with) implemented this kind of thing for an internal tool we use pretty easy. Of course will not work with all the custom query strings from various companies around the world, but you know, the query strings used by big players are commonly known (Amazon, Google, Facebook, Twitter, etc).

One thing to also have in mind are the affiliate links. Maybe you want to send a link to someone, having the affiliate query string. Maybe some options here might get useful.

I think query parameters are often the least invasive and most privacy respecting ways of “tracking” in existence today. I put tracking in scare quotes because it’s really just how you get metrics on how people are finding your content, where they come from, etc. This data is very important for businesses and creators.

After all, they’re not trying to “pull one over” on you. The query params are clearly listed for people to see.

Also, lots of web apps use query parameters for user convenience. I use them to let people customize my web apps immediately upon startup without needing some kind of user account.

Just like how photos are manipulated and videos are reprocessed, I would prefer Signal do as I ask it to, instead of trying to second-guess me (I do understand and appreciate why photos and videos are reprocessed).

I barely ever get a browser when opening links these days, since I have the native app for most of them installed. Also note I’m on iOS, so the browser is always going to be safari anyway.

I get your point that stripping utm data is an issue for some use-cases, that’s why I’ve pointed out multiple possible solutions. Your concern would be addressed by having it as an option that you need to enable if you’re sure that this is what you want, or having a button that becomes visible when tracking parameters are detected, suggesting removal by tapping it, but doesn’t do anything automatically on its own.

The request is very similar, but I think the other issue is more abstract and a little harder to reason about. This one is explicitly about query parameters that are known to be used for tracking or mapping my personal social network (like igshid does), while the other thread appeears to be on long urls in general (therefore causing concern about “incorrectly cleaning a link”).

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
Automatically strip tracking/UTM parameters

this is still filtering the message content, which doesn’t feel right, on principle.

I think it is comparable to the stripping of exif data in images that Signal does.

There are a lot of different things at play here:

  • Stripping params on input might lead to bad UX as the cursor jumps around.
  • Stripping all params might actually break some links (e.g. Flynn prepared to testify that Trump directed him to contact Russians about ISIS, confidant says - ABC News)
  • Whitelist params? Or blacklist them? And who maintains the list, either way?
  • Obfuscating parameters is not difficult - a site could just hide them in ?base_64_params=aaba318fc93d57 (actually Facebook base64 encodes their on-site params, or they used to)
  • Sometimes people mean to send links with the parameters in them for affiliate links or what-have-you

I also I hate manually removing query parameters all the time, but it might be better to have a setting that visually removes the parameters when you read the URL and strips the parameters when you click on a link on the receiver’s end. That way it can be turned off if it interferes with anything. Maybe it can be a conversation setting.

posts.name: Nova
posts.cooked: Maybe something that would make this feature more palatable is having it be an opt-in setting. That would alleviate concerns around Signal modifying messages unintentionally. Even if just a few basic parameters are whitelisted, like utm_* and igshid, it would go a long way towards improving privacy for users.

FYI for developers, ClearURL actually has a repo with all the rules for filtering and cleaning social media links for privacy. I think this really should be baked into signals to enhance privacy as @rassilon1963 pointed out and if you look at the json below… it’s relatively intuitive.

posts.name: Neo1992
posts.cooked: For better privacy auto-remove share tracking URL querystring parameters, e.g. the “si” parameter for instagram, the “t” parameter from Twitter etc. These parameters are an extremely invasive and powerful way to map an individual’s network of contacts.

posts.name: Frank Löffler
posts.cooked: The reason given by the OP for cleaning was mainly “taking up a lot of space”. Another approach that would solve this and which would not change the URL is to hide it: ideally using markdown syntax: [TEXT](LINK). This way, the link isn’t even visible and wouldn’t take up any space. The only question remaining would be whether or not to provide or require a pop-up to ask whether it is ok to open that link when clicking - at least on devices and in apps that don’t support “hover” or don’t show the link when hovering (think of browsers, where this is the standard way to show link targets).
